Creating a Workspace

Note: in the steps that follow, we assume that you have a network storage location mapped as a drive letter. We'll refer to this location as U:, but use whichever letter you actually have assigned for it.

First, create a location for your Eclipse workspace. This is just a directory in which Eclipse will organize your Java projects and files and will keep track of various settings.

  1. First make a directory U:\cs227. (E.g., go to your U: drive in File Explorer, right-click, and select New...Folder.)
  2. Then within that directory, create a directory called workspace

Next, start Eclipse. In the lab machines, you can just search for "eclipse". If you are using your own machine, you may want to create a shortcut to the executable file eclipse.exe located in the eclipse/bin directory. On a Mac, look for the file called Eclipse.app.

  1. Double-click the icon or shortcut to start Eclipse. (If a dialog appears asking you to confirm that you want to run the executable, select Run.)
  2. Eclipse brings a dialog asking for a workspace location. Usually there is a default value filled in. This default location is probably on the C: drive and should not be used if you are in lab.
  3. For the workspace location, type in the absolute path for the workspace directory you created earlier: 
    U:\cs227\workspace
  4. After Eclipse starts, click on the X on the tab to get rid of the welcome screen.

The next time you start Eclipse, the same dialog will come up asking you for a workspace location, and you'll find that a default value has been filled in. such as U:\cs227\workspace will already be filled in. In most cases this is just fine, but remember one thing: If you map your network storage using a different drive letter the next time you work in the lab, you'll need to retype the workspace location using the new drive letter when you start Eclipse.

The next few simple exercises will acquaint you with the basics of creating a Java class in Eclipse.
